Introduction

Inflammatory breast cancer is a rare, aggressive form of breast cancer with a rapid onset.  Patients typically experience unilateral breast pain and diffuse erythema, edema, and warmth of the overlying skin, which produces a classic peau d'orange appearance (

figure 1
).

Pathogenesis and risk factors



The term "inflammatory" breast cancer is a misnomer because the cancer's characteristic skin findings are not caused by inflammation.



Inflammatory breast cancer is classically due to the invasion of tumor cells into the dermal lymphovascular spaces.  Obstruction of the dermal lymphatics causes severe cutaneous edema.  As a result, the breast becomes firm, erythematous, and coarsely pitted like an orange peel (peau d'orange), resulting in the inflammatory appearance.



Inflammatory breast cancer tends to present at an earlier age than other forms of breast cancer, likely due to its early invasion of the lymphatic system and other aggressive attributes: It is highly angiogenic (ie, rapid tumor growth) and angioinvasive (ie, hematogeneous spread).  Metastasis occurs within months and is present in up to 20% of newly diagnosed patients.



Because it is a rare diagnosis, risk factors are not well established.

Clinical presentation



Patients typically have the following symptoms:



  • Unilateral breast pain
  • Enlarging breast mass
  • Diffuse, erythematous, itchy rash over the affected breast
  • Rapid onset of symptoms over the course of weeks to months


On examination, the affected breast typically has:



  • Diffuse edema/enlargement and warmth to the touch
  • Thickened and erythematous skin with dimpling (peau d'orange)
  • Axillary lymphadenopathy (even on initial presentation due to the propensity for early lymphatic invasion)


Some patients have nipple changes (eg, crusting, retraction) and a palpable breast mass.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis is based on characteristic clinical features plus invasive carcinoma on histopathology.  Clinical features include rapid-onset (<6 months) breast erythema, edema, warmth and/or a peau d'orange appearance.



Breast biopsy (eg, core needle biopsy) and histopathology are performed to confirm invasive carcinoma.  Full-thickness skin punch biopsy is obtained to assess tumor invasion of the dermal lymphatic spaces, which is a characteristic finding.  However, this finding is not required for making the diagnosis due to sampling errors and occasionally because it is an incidental finding.



In addition, patients with suspected inflammatory breast cancer require diagnostic mammography of the affected breast and screening mammography of the contralateral breast.  Mammography typically reveals skin thickening and, possibly, a mass, architectural distortion, or area of calcification.  Ultrasonography of the breast and axillary lymph nodes is also performed to evaluate for metastasis.

Differential diagnosis



  • Mastitis:  This is the most common misdiagnosis associated with inflammatory breast cancer.  Mastitis also presents with unilateral breast pain, swelling, and skin erythema; mammography reveals skin thickening.  Unlike inflammatory breast cancer, mastitis usually causes signs of inflammation (eg, fever, malaise, leukocytosis).  Axillary lymphadenopathy is uncommon, except in severe cases.  Mastitis improves with antibiotics; lack of improvement should prompt evaluation for inflammatory breast cancer (ie, via biopsy).
  • Inflammatory skin conditions (eg, contact dermatitis, cellulitis):  Such conditions may present with localized erythema, warmth, and pruritus of the skin overlying the breast.  Diffuse breast enlargement and axillary lymphadenopathy are uncommon.
  • Other forms of breast cancer:  Noninflammatory breast cancers can present with skin changes (eg, nipple retraction, ulceration) and axillary lymphadenopathy.  However, not all skin changes associated with breast cancer meet the criteria for inflammatory breast cancer, which is defined by multiple, diffuse skin changes that occur rapidly and simultaneously.  Noninflammatory breast cancers typically cause localized or isolated skin changes.

Management



Similar to other forms of breast cancer, inflammatory breast cancer is assessed for hormone (estrogen and progesterone) receptor status and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) status because the results can alter the prognosis and management options.



Patients also require complete evaluation for distant metastases, including CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis and a bone scan.



Because of the aggressive nature of inflammatory breast cancer, treatment typically requires a multimodal approach.  Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is administered first to decrease tumor burden and facilitate surgical intervention.  Then patients typically undergo mastectomy and lymph node dissection followed by radiation therapy.  Breast-conserving surgery (eg, lumpectomy) is contraindicated due to the severity of disease and high rates of recurrence.

Prognosis



Inflammatory breast cancer is associated with a poorer prognosis compared to other forms of breast cancer due to its propensity for early metastasis and high rates of early recurrence.  Poor prognostic features are similar to other forms of breast cancer, including negative progesterone/estrogen receptor status, HER2-negative status, and lack of response to chemotherapy.

Summary



Inflammatory breast cancer is a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer characterized by the rapid onset of diffuse skin erythema, edema, and warmth, as well as a peau d'orange appearance, in the affected breast.  Diagnosis is based on characteristic clinical features and biopsy results that confirm invasive carcinoma.  Treatment is multimodal (eg, chemotherapy, surgery, radiation therapy).
